comments.commentBody:
Most readers assume that the corporate funds now held overseas are due simply to foreign sales. The profits held there are actually due because the rights to derive income from foreign and Us sales Have been moved to tax havens. Those rights are mainly intellectual property assets, created by workers - designers, programmers, marketing experts - that have been transferred to corporate subsidiaries in tax havens at pennies per dollar of future income from licensing the rights to that IP.
if the IP is not repatriated with any dollars it will stay in the tax havens and continue to amass funds there.
While the dollars appear in corporate books and show that the corporations are doing great, the intellectual assets do not, and allow the profits due to US cretive workers to be hidden in tax havens, invisibly to the government, the workers, and the readers of the New York Times.

End the "volunteer army"..... few of these people are truly volunteering, they just don't have any other options. As long as we have this type of army we will have this political posing by our dear leader.
Many Americans are over-medicated and over-treated, which leads to a variety of complications and negative outcomes. Hence, it may not always be detrimental for patients to be non-compliant.

I'm not an Obama fan and wish we had someone real for a president but what, ladies and gens, do you want him to do in this situation?

Cut-n-run? If he does, there will be an immediate blood bath and takeover of the country by the Taliban with a likely creation of the most anti-American axis we've seen Pak-Afg-Iran. No matter their quarrels and grievances, their hate of the West and US will unite them. It won't be an 'axis of evil' but axis of death.

We need to modify our Afghan military doctrine (no more moronic 'winning the hearts') to allow a controlled withdrawal with an option of having a handful of bases from where we could watch and intervene if needed. It's time Pentagon started thinking strategically, because it looks like it's too much to expect from our PINO (president in name only).

I did not have to read the article to know which way the court wen on this decision. I knew the outcome of this decision the moment it left the circuit court.

The US Supreme Court has become an extension of the political circus which our democracy has become. I no longer see the legitimacy of a court that claims to be a system of blind justice-where every issue that comes before it is decided on it's merits-without the taint of any type of partiallity.

The US Supreme Court-with it's 9 justices-no longer holds the immaculate prestige and high-regard that it used to, and thereby must be held to account for all their actions through elections just as the legislative and executive branches are.

Enough is enough! They must earn their job through national election; handing it to them with a lifetime appointment should no longer be what it has to been, irrespective of what the constitution says. Time to modernize the court by adding a new ammendment to the constitution.
If the stock holders want their money then let the move overseas and spend it. They made their bed now either pay the Taxes or Move.

The NYT has outdone itself in self-parody with this one.

As amusing as the article was, I'd much rather have read on Father's Day an inspiring story of a strong single father who in spite of the odds, overcomes challenges every day of which these whiny fruitcakes in this self-indulgent article have no inkling.

Griffin will be fine; he'll land a job at the Times after graduating from Oberlin.

We went to Afghanistan on an ill-designed mission to wipe out al Qaeda, not to overthrow the Taliban (which would be just taking sides in the Afghan civil war). Somehow Obama lost sight of that. He has made the same mistake in Libya.

Bring all the troops home now, and end the extra-judicial assassinations.

This confirms that the business world's most successful & wealthiest sector is the most un-American corner of our society.  Its greed is so vast that it is incapable of considering that its success can, and does, devastate the nation and the lives of millions of Americans.  The combination of corporations, banks and Wall Street rivals Al Queda in the cost to the welfare of the USA.

You know, I keep reading comments from people saying that this was a unanimous decision and anyone not seeing that should read the decision. Did you?

I see a 5 to 4 decision and a 9 to 0 decision. The "unanimous" decision involved procedural point. No problem. Your right, it was unanimous. But the other decision was ideological which, of course is where the controversy is.

Whether or not you agree with this decision you need look no further than Scalia's comments to see what is really going on. He has set a nearly impossible standard for bringing large class action lawsuits. All a company has to do is put a national policy in writing and then tell the branches they can do whatever they want to do. Under this standard the parent company cannot be held accountable for the actions of their branches.

For those of you that are not aware of it, having a society where corporations are not held accountable for their actions is exactly what the hard line radical right wing is accomplishing with this court. Maybe it's time you read the whole article instead of the cliff notes.

people think they can get ahead by voting for Republican presidents, who appoint members of the supreme court, who hand down these types of decisions. until those voters change and start electing Democrats to
the White House, big business will continue to get away with these types
of practices.
Homework is important. We just need to get rid of "busy work" and outlandish projects.

Take the Metro (best subway system in Europe, hands down) to La Latina station, some time around 9 pm or later in the weekend, and just take a stroll around Plaza de la Cebada, Cava Baja, Plaza de la Paja... the ambient is great. A little bit more closer to Plaza Mayor, all the narrow streets are pretty awesome too. The walk from el Viaducto bridge in the south limit of La Latina to Plaza España by the Palacio Real is outstanding.
The area around Conde Duque, by Plaza España is nice too. Madrid is probably one of the most underrated capital cities in Europe. It is not as flooded with tourists as Rome, Paris or London, but my be more fun and unpretentious than most of them.

An individual US citizen who earns a profit in a foreign transaction pays US income tax on that profit in the year that it is earned. Why does a US corporation not pay US taxes on its foreign profits when they are earned, regardless of where the funds are kept?

Could it be that corporations' lobbyists have influenced the tax code written by the US Congress which needs the lobbyists money to stay in office?

Well it's good to see that there are still many Tiger fans still out there. But to the extent that they dismiss Rory McIlroy, they are only repeating what their hated adversaries do with respect to Woods.

McIlroy was immaculate this week. Praise him for that. Will he dominate golf as Tiger did? No, because golf is in a different place now, with any number of competitors who could win week to week. And that's good for golf. Having said that, will Rory break Jack's (or Tiger's) record for major championships? Well, he's just past his 22nd birthday and has factored in the last 4 majors. DUH.

Michael Cornelius

www.onsportsandlife.com

Beyond the magic of the camaraderie and spirit of brotherhood Clarence inspired, he was the premier rock saxophonist of this or any era.   His soulfulness and melodic sense was without peer in any genre you care to mention.  His playing always fit the song, from the still stunning and epic solo in Jungleland to the yearning coda on Secret Garden.  That we'll never see him play again is a loss difficult to accept, and his passing a potent reminder that every day is, and every night I saw him play, a gift.

What surprised me was the unanimous opinion.  I thought for sure at least 1 or 2 of the court's intellectual southpaw's would dissent.  The fact that none did emphasizes the court's position on the attempted stretching of class-action laws by the plaintiffs.

At last!  A possible attorney full-unemployment action!  Good riddance to ambulance chasers!--though admittedly not germane to the present case.  Next up, full tort reform.  Possibly to follow, loser pays all costs.  Let all those who would go to law school instead earn an honest living doing other positive/meaningful work.

Same old 5-4 split every time by the same judges- the supreme court only uses the law to mask its conservative ideology. It no longer decides cases on the basis of applying the facts to the law. The court risks losing all credibility and with it's legitimacy.

This story is not over.  Even the Supreme Court cannot wave away a million and a half women!  This might be the end of  this lawsuit, but it is the beginning of a new labor movement in this country.  Fasten your seatbelts!

This story is not over.  Even the Supreme Court cannot wave away a million and a half women!  This might be the end of  this lawsuit, but it is the beginning of a new labor movement in this country.  Fasten your seatbelts!

A brand new ethical law needs to be passed which allows for half men and at least half women on the Supreme Court bench. The way it has been ran for over 200 years is the laughing stock of any real ethics. For over 200 years only two women & now recently three women have served on the Supreme Court bench. It is tyrannical and undeserving of anything near a court of law! It is a mockery to humankind! America has to lift is terrible long held oppression over women and put women's faces on monetary bills and women have to Unite in a more powerful manner than in past eras. March on Washington DC and remember when women had to march just to get the right to vote and not be beat up for lifting their skirts above the ankle.  Women need to also be first of choice for those trillion dollar bailouts instead of the predominent majority men who received the funding! It isn't fair and we are not going to take it anymore! We cannot allow a bunch of old schooled men make decisions for 1.5 million women and reject the Supreme Court decision because it is biased and unjust! It is not a sound decision based on the Proper Human Excelences which dictates that you remove all barriers in those women's lives that obstruct them from reaching their highest potential in life.

I know that I am not on topic, but my dispute with the Walmart is simple.  They targeted every small town and took down their Main Street.  They destroyed everything that was decent and quaint about small towns.  All the businesses that were there are now just old junk stores.  Nothing like taking rural America and bending it to it's knees.  Small towns are not a nice picture today.  People in small towns may be grateful to work for minimum wage with no benefits at their local Walmart.  What else can they do?  The people that used to have a place no longer do.

I agree with the comments here; the workplace is the problem.

but, this story is not over. Even the largest U.S. retail company and the Supreme Court cannot wave away a million and a half women! This might be the end of this lawsuit, but it is the beginning of a new labor movement in this country. Fasten your seatbelts!

A new Supreme court which oversees the Sureme Court needs to be formed and all its members: women.  200 years of male dominated male chauvanism on the Supreme court where only three women have served since its inception is a bad joke under heaven or hell!  It took a very long time for men to realize that women should and could vote, wear dresses above their ankles, write books, write holy literature, re-write laws, and be leaders in their own right! I feel an overall lack of Ethics education is lacking in most males in government with any degree high or lower.  Try Dr. Hale for an ethics class and require all justices to undergo his classes.  I really do not accept laws made by a Supreme Court where men are not ethical enough to service the nation fairly. You all understand that most of Walt-Mart employees cannot afford the high price of hourly attorneys indivually. We all understand this whether subconsciously or consciously.  By the way I don't shop at Walt-Mart. I think I understand my reasons now; not knowing prior.  Men should be fighting here to change themselves instead of pointing the finger overseas where they abuse and oppress women instead.
